pros: Great people to work with
cons: There were no cons. I would go back anytime!

pros: flexible hours, let’s you work independently
cons: they post the exact job you do online for more money, when you ask why it is like that they straight up lie to you. then when you ask for a raise due to this, as well as just in general with inflation (and you are already making $3 less an hour with the current market average) they tell you no lol. does not give much training. the past year they made it so they could combine holiday and PTO all into one, but don’t worry, they made it so you have less time off with this!!! they do not even allow part time people to get benefits now when they used to. insurance is a very high deductible. your grandparents aren’t considered immediate family in their eyes so when they die you must work, so be prepared for that. they do not care. i’ve talked to others and have seen good people leave this company due to paying so little. i’m glad others have left and doubled their salary, but i am so sad that it even has to come to this when the ceo made over half a mil just last year.

pros: Friendly coworkers, free parking, diverse patient population
cons: Low salary with yearly raises often way below inflation. Management only cares about the bottom dollar. They prioritize money over staff and patient safety. Staff is overworked in every hospital department, often doing the job of two people.

pros: Lots of current changes focused on continual process improvement and lean management
cons: Fair compensation currently in comparison to similar jobs.

pros: Overall, clinical staff work together as a team and support one another. The nurses and nursing assistants truly care about patients. Diverse workplace.
cons: Organization's longstanding mission and values are being eroded by incoming senior management. Used to feel like you were part of a community and where patient care was priority. Now it's becoming like every other profit-driven hospital system. Near impossible for nurses to get PTO, health insurance has ridiculously high deductible, chronically under-staffed (by design), high burnout and turnover.

review_title: The good, the bad, and the ugly
pros: Great co-workers (many with great experience/expertise), good facility, generally nice equipment/supplies, some opportunities for education.  Lost of extra stuff like specialty programs.  PTO accrues faster than other places I have worked.  Retirement benefits on par or slightly better than some places.  Health care benefit at least on par with other companies I've seen.
cons: Maybe this is my perception but it seemed as if things started to go down hill in the work/life balance category after John Crystal took over who has since left.  Focus seemed to go more towards money/productivity.  We were expected 90% productivity which often required you to see 2 patients at a time.  Pay was 8hrs/day so if you ran late with documentation it was on you (not paid or comp time).  I was frequently told to cover other departments: instead of staying in out-patient (my department) I was sent out to do home visits for weeks at a time, I filled in for in-patient therapists, sometimes I took the job of a patient tech (passing out breakfast trays and feeding dependent patients).  I was frequently denied the use of my PTO (or at least told to wait until the last minute for approval depending on census).  If weather was bad I was expected to come in even though all my patients would cancel.  Frequent, unpaid, lunch meetings (technically optional but if you didn't go they noticed).  There was a subtle tendency for sycophants to be treated better.

review_title: Great place - - and getting even better.
pros: The people who work at Good Shepherd are really passionate about what they do.  It is also a place where people at all levels believe and live the mission every day.  I'm very excited about the new CEO.  He has really embraced and supports the Raker legacy.
cons: There is a need to enhance technology for the business.  There is great technology for patients but there is a needs to be equally advanced technology for the rest of the company.

review_title: Great co-workers, outside the IT Department
pros: The Raker legacy.   Passionate about patient care.  Passionate about our residents.   Excellent Outpatient sites, our therapists are the best!
cons: Lack of leadership in certain departments.  Terrible IT department, they need to support the company, NOT sabotage it.   They cannot keep new hard working employees because the senior slacker employees create such an unhealthy work environment it just is not worth it.

pros: Pay decent.  I can’t think of anything else.
cons: Pay decent.  Benefits awful.  HR unresponsive.  IT unresponsive.  In a state of terrible turnover.  Temporary employees in key roles.  All management cares about is gossip.  Your review is based on gossip and not actual work done.  Too many chiefs not enough Indians.  Unqualified managers / micromanaging employees while they ignore big picture.  Don’t waste your time.

pros: I started out with the system in one capacity and began working in another due to a work injury. I am grateful to remain employed. Support has been positive.
cons: The people I'm in contact with on a daily basis are great. The challenge comes when the people in Allentown make decisions on your behalf without ever speaking to you.

pros: Good Shepherd is a great place to work at. Most people are professional and friendly. They use the latest technology available for rehabilitation. Due to the availability of inpatient and outpatient services in main campus, you would be able to see your clients progress.
cons: The only reason why I had to leave Good Shepherd was the location. I am a city person, and decided to move out the state.

pros: Mission driven culture.  Seeks to partner with other organizations.  Forward looking.  Diversified post-acute provider.  Relationships with Penn Medicine and CHOP in Philadelphia.
cons: Heavily dependent on area acute care systems for hospital referrals.  Will be a challenge to succeed financially under future healthcare reimbursement environment.  But that is true of all healthcare providers.
